course.subject: COMP
course.name: Principles of Cybersecurity
course.description: This course is an introduction to the principles of cybersecurity. Cybersecurity, also called computer security or IT security, refers to the study of techniques to protect computing systems from attacks that threaten data confidentiality, system integrity and availability. By modeling, analyzing, and evaluating the security of computer systems, students will learn to find weaknesses in software, hardware, networks, data storage systems, mobile applications, and the Internet, and identify current security practices and defenses to protect these systems.
course.prerequisites: COMP 2012 OR COMP 2012H

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: HACK101 Introduction to Hacking
reviews.comment_content:
This is mostly a conceptual course about cybersecurity. Lots of interesting theories in cybersecurity are introduced. There are five main parts in the course:

1. Security basics: CIA principle, threat models
2. Cryptography: Stream and block ciphers, RSA, hashing
3. Software security: Buffer overflow, obfuscation, malware, security testing
4. System & web security: Authentication, access control, side channel attacks, firewalls
5. Security on emerging platforms: Blockchain, smart contract, IoT, machine learning

Have you ever imagine you can infer the password by recording the sound while encrypting? How to fool a machine learning AI to label a dog as 'cat'? How does a hacker steal all the cryptocurrency from badly designed code? Cybersecurity is always an interesting topic in computer science. For the level of this course, it only gives a general introduction but not heavy maths nor programming. It should be suitable and fun for most CS students.

The only hands-on experience for hacking is the optional project. We are given a vulnerable website to conduct different types of attacks. For example, bypassing the login, stealing the passwords, or even hang up the site. Although the way to hack is not covered in class, it is fun to explore around and learn by yourself. You will be rofl when you have found a stupid vulnerability in the site.

P.S. <b>Be ethical. Don't attempt to hack others without permission.</b>
reviews.comment_teaching:
The prof. seems to be a nice and passionate guy. I haven't talked with him in person. But he sometimes asks us questions and tells some funny things in class. He also left a "well done, thanks for your effort." comment on my exam submission. Maybe I did well in questions that are his research topic. (My classmate and I found his research paper when searching for info in final lol) I only sent him email once and he did not respond. Maybe he missed it by mistake.  

He teaches okay. He is not a "PowerPoint" reading guy. He usually will put some time explaining the slides. But it is dubious whether everyone could understand the explanations as they are quite messy.  And his tone is ..., I think I slept quite a few times in his lecture. :C

Martin, the course TA, is a weird but funny guy. He likes joking about how lazy he is. "The worse TA in UST" he claimed. He don't know how to teach and always give out the answers "accidentally". He gave us some midterm tips but they are not that useful......  Anyway, I admire his courage to speak "______, ______!" when he was testing the mic. Hope he won't be silenced or get fired.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading curve seems to be similar or better than a standard course. However, being one of the top students is not easy that it requires some luck and effort.

The midterm and exam is quite difficult. Since there is not any paper checking session (and answers are not given), you would not be able to argue your marks. IMO the TA seems to be quite strict with the marking, you won't be able to get score for alternative answers. As this is a cybersecurity course, the questions are mainly case-studies which multiple answers may arise.

There is an optional project that can pull up your score. It seems only a few people have attempted it. It is difficult for first time hacker (like me). But still, there should be no problem completing it with some googling (for hints). The weighting is quite high (completing it equals 15 points in midterm!) so it should secure you from getting a bad grade. My scores in midterm and final are under the top (max score) student quite a bit but I still got an A.

Final (30%):

Participation (10%):
10/10 (Mean: 8.3, Max: 10)
Optional Project (4%, bonus):
100% completed, score unknown
Overall:
86.91% (+?.??% project) => A

All SD are not released. Optional project score is not released.
(I have sent an email to both the prof. and TA asking the optional project score (on Dec 18). There is still no response as of the time writing this review.)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of the course is moderate.

The assignments are quite long. You usually cannot find the answer directly in the slides. You have to recall the things talked in class and understand the content in order to answer. Alternatively, you can ask Martin to get the answer directly......

As the prof. is new, the course format has revamped and there isn't any past paper. Most likely, you won't have materials for revision. I think reviewing the materials once should be fine since there isn't anything more you can do. Just write the answers and hope for the best.

There are in-class quizzes. The dates of the quizzes are not announced. The questions are easy (~2 questions, answers can be found in slides) as those are simply for attendance checking. Make sure to attend the lectures or ask your friend to submit it for you.

The optional project took me two days to complete. You have to do self-learning for the project. With hints from Google and some trial and error, it should be feasible to complete the project. It takes some time to get the attacks right. It is fun to craft up the attack tho, and you will feel a sense of accomplishment when you successfully attacked the target. I AM A MASTER HACKER HAHA! (just kidding)

reviews.author: Argen
reviews.title: Nice Prof., Updated Content, Interesting HW/Project
reviews.comment_content:
Wang Tao focuses on "Principles" of cybersecurity, while Wang Shuai's content is more biased to "Practice" and "Examples". The theoretical part of the course is cut to a large proportion, and replaced with content related to his own research — Cybersecurity in Software Engineering.

If you would like to learn more about software safety, security analysis, and possible leak holes in different applications, this course with Shuai is an eye-opener for you.

A brief outline of the content
1. Introduction (same principles)
2. Symmetric Keys Cryptography
3. Public-private Key Cryptography and Hashes
4. Reverse Engineering
5. Malware and Attacks
6. Software Obfuscation
7. Fuzzing, Taint Analysis and Side-Channel Attacks
8. Biometric Passwords
9. Network Security
10. Blockchain and Smart Contracts
11. IoT and Machine Learning Security

Upon the topics, I think (6), (7) and (11) are unique topics of Shuai.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not bad, if you are fine with his accent. His lecture is slightly boring but informative. He is eager to know any feedback on his teaching and content as he does not have much teaching experience. And he responds to emails very quickly.

In the lecture, he explained things pretty well and usually discussed a lot using the whiteboard. Content of elaboration written on the whiteboard might be tested and not necessarily mentioned in the notes. So attending the class is important not to mention the in-class quizzes.

General speaking, Shuai is not bad, though some may suggest Tao teaches better.
reviews.comment_grading:
Don't underestimate the importance of assignments and participation. They matter a lot in this course, especially when there are only 3 in-class in my semester (edited: you will get 7 + number of completed quiz for your mark.)
10% - Participation and in-class quizzes
40% - Assignments
20% - Midterm exam
30% - Final exam
4%   - Optional Project

Shuai tried to distribute good grades but got rejected by the department. In the end, he strictly follows the distribution suggested by the university.
~15% A
~35% B
~40% C
If you get mean or slightly above mean, you can expect a C+/B-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair.

4 Assignments: each ~8 long questions and can be finished within 3 hours. For some questions you are expected to google for answer/hint. Shuai likes to ask whether some techniques solve/improve certain issues very much. Some questions in the assignments can reappear in midterm/final.

In-class exercise (attendance): just to answer 2-3 simple questions. They can be found easily in the notes.

Optional Project: Some web penetration to the OWASP project. It requires a lot of self-learning and effort for trial-and-error. It provides an opportunity for beginners to keep in touch with tools in the cybersecurity field like elasticsearch (logging tools), Burp Suite (web hacking), hashcat (password crack), etc. For the solution, Google it and you'll find everything.

reviews.author: Xelopie
reviews.title: !!!!!!Fair Conceptual Course!!!!!!
reviews.comment_content:
--------------------------Spoiler warning here--------------------------
If you are aiming to learn real hacking stuff or CTF thingys, I suggest you not to take this course and stop reading now. If you are aiming to improve your knowledge of security for workspace, then you might consider this course. Personally I have little background on game hacking.
--------------------------Real Content here----------------------------
(I just type out the topic according to syllabus, skip this part if you just want to read comments)
1. Symmetric key crypto
2. Public key crypto
3. Hash function
4. Reverse engineering
5. Malware
6. Software exploitation & protection & analysis
7. Side channel attacks
8. Authentication & Authorization + Network security
9. Protocol
10. Bitcoin stuffs (blockchain + smart contract)
11. Machine learning security
-----------------------------Comments--------------------------------
1. Lots lots lots of concept, very high level stuffs and ideas
2. Just very basic and simplified idea taught in lectures
3. Real implementation is relatively not important in this course
4. IDEAs are important, POSSIBILITIES too !!!!! (but how are you gonna know if your idea is possible if you don't implement it)
5. Rely to GOOGLE, please google everything
6. Ideas in crypto/side-channel are really hard to just imagine
7. Other topics are fairly fine to me
---------------------------Final reminder------------------------------
Really don't expect too much from this course. It won't help you write a simple modern hacking tool. It just brings you concepts (or even mindset? who cares?)

reviews.author: nar
reviews.title: professor 係 cs 清泉
reviews.comment_content:
Modules:
- Principles of Cybersecurity: "CIA", secure design
- Software Security: intentional flaws, unintentional flaws, malware classificiation, defensive strategies
- Internet Security and Privacy: cryptosystems (SKE, PKE), integrity verification and authentication (cryptographic hash, MAC, PKI), cryptosystem attacks
- Network Security and Privacy: network basics, impersonation attacks, DoS attacks, defences (firewall, VPN, Tor)
- Data Security and Privacy: data security (access control, error checking/correction, backup), data privacy (inference attack, k-Anonymity, differential privacy, secure multiparty computation, private information retrieval), bitcoin
- Human Cybersecurity: socio-legal cybersecurity, cybersecurity in business, usable security and privacy
留意返呢個 course 真係講 principles，唔會涉獵到太深入嘅技術層面或者係 implementation。其實幾合理，淨係講 cryptosystems 已經可以係一個 course。
attack examples 由舊(定係叫classical?)到新都有

Assessment:
- Assignment * 3 (45%)
- Self-Assessment (for each module) (5%)
- Midterm (20%)
- Final (30%)
下次 course offering midterm 同 final 嘅比重會係一樣，因為考試係 non-cumulative

reviews.author: delf
reviews.title: Great Instructor, Appropriate Content, Fun Programming Assignments
reviews.comment_content:
The content for the course was well selected and taught at an appropriate level for an introductory course to cybersecurity. A large number of topics were covered but the material did not go too in depth so it was all easy to understand. Will help you get a good idea of the current cybersecurity landscape and the practices followed.

Taking this course was very useful for internship/job interviews because interviewers usually asked some simple cybersecurity related questions (public key cryptography).
reviews.comment_teaching: One of the most interesting and motivated lecturers I have had at UST. He was very well versed in the course materials and was available to explain things in depth after class. Lectures were always interesting as there was a lot of discussion and he would supplement the lecture materials with his own experiences and real world events.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was quite fair. Exams required you to know the lecture materials well, taking notes in class was necessary as lecture slides do not contain a lot of information.

45% - 3x Assignments (15%)
A1 mean: 67.3/75
A2 mean: 51.8/75
A3 mean: 50.8/75

5% - Online Self-Assessment
Questions were pretty straightforward

20% - Mid-term Exam
Mean: 58.7/80

30% - Final Exam
Mean: 76.8/120
reviews.comment_workload:
The assignments were not trivial, they required some time to think about, but they were also well thought out and at an adequate level of difficulty. Working on the programming tasks was a lot of fun and there was also a lot of freedom in the implementation of the assignments.

Going to class is necessary since most of the information came from what the professor said in class rather than slides. The whole value of the course came from the lecture though so it would be pointless to take this course and not go to class.
